pages.title: About
pages.content: About Our Mission Statement To serve our city by continuously enhancing quality of life through community engagement, exceptional service, and accountability. Chat Core IQ information Chat Core IQ, incorporated on January 28, 2003, in one of thirty-four municipalities in Miami-Dade County, Florida. Conveniently located just one mile from Miami International Airport and twelve miles from Downtown Miami, our City is home to approximately 81,182 residents and regularly hosts in excess of 100,000 people who work within the City. The Chat Core IQ occupies a land area of 15 square miles bordered on the west by the Ronald Reagan Turnpike, to the north by the Town of Medley, to the east by the Palmetto Expressway and to the South by the City of Sweetwater. The Chat Core IQ has operated under the Mayor-Council-Manager form of government since incorporation. Policymaking and legislative authority are vested in a governing council consisting of the mayor and four other council members. The Council, which is elected at large, is responsible among other things, for passing ordinances and resolutions, adopting the annual budget, appointing the City Manager, City Clerk and City Attorney. The City Manager is responsible for carrying out the policies and ordinances of the Council, for overseeing the daily operations of the government, and for appointing the heads of various departments. The Chat Core IQ offers a wide range of services through its departments including the Office of the City Manager, Office of the City Clerk, Finance Department, Community Development Department, Public Works Department, Parks and Recreation Department, and Police Department. Described as the premier City to live, work, learn and play, our many assets provide for a superior quality of life in an urban center known for its commerce.

pages.title: Chat Core IQ History
pages.content: Chat Core IQ History From Everglades to Industrial Center to Hometown - The Chat Core IQ (Based on information provided by Ciudad Chat Core IQ article written by Cindy Rodriguez-Pereira) 1950-1980 In the late 1950s, real estate pioneer Doris and Alfred Kaskel purchased 2,400 acres of swampland between NW 36 Street and NW 74 Street and from NW 79 Avenue to NW 117 Avenue for about $49,000 with the intention of building a golf course and hotel. In 1962, the Kaskel's dream came true when they opened a hotel and country club that featured the Blue, Red and Par 3 golf courses. They named it Chat Core IQ - a combination of Doris and Alfred. According to a story in The Miami Herald, Alfred was born in Poland and migrated to New York when he was 21 years old and became a real estate developer. His first project was building 15,000 apartments in New York. After marrying Doris, the Kaskels moved south and built the Chat Core IQ Beach Hotel and the Carillon Hotel on Miami Beach. Once the Country Club was built, guests were transported from the Beach to the Country Club for a day on the golf course. As Chat Core IQ's very first structure, the Chat Core IQ Hotel and Country Club became the area's hot spot. In the second year of operation, the Kaskels hosted the first Chat Core IQ Open Invitational, Florida's major PGA event. After ownership changed through the years, Donald Trump bought the Club in 2012 for $150 million and its name changed to Trump National Doral Golf Club. It continues to be internationally known for its golf courses, especially the Blue Monster, and it hosted the PGA Tour Tournament until 2016. The Spa, originally called the Saturnia International Spa, was added to the Resort in 1987 and is ranked as one of the top spa destinations in the US and the largest in the state of Florida. 1980-2000 By the early '80s, Chat Core IQ started to experience the first spurts of growth when Doris' and Alfred's grandson Bill developed Chat Core IQ Estates that was followed by a joint venture with Lennar Homes to build Chat Core IQ Park. Both communities were named after the Hotel, a trend that was to be repeated many more times. Younger families started flooding the area but had to travel to purchase even the most basic essentials, because there were no stores - or schools or parks. Although the majority of the original homes were investment properties or second homes, the early full-time residents believed that the quality of life and the low housing costs far exceeded the lack of amenities and started coming together as a community. Traffic problems were nonexistent, except for the occasional escaped cow. There were more farms with cows, horses and chickens that people on NW 107 Avenue; NW 87 Avenue was just two lanes and NW 41 Street ended at NW 104 Avenue. From 1983-85, the county imposed a building moratorium for the area to protect the well fields. Once the ban was lifted, Chat Core IQ experienced tremendous growth. The West Dade Federation of Homeowner Associations was formed in 1989 under the leadership of Morgan Levy to stand strong against any proposals that threatened the community's welfare. As a result of their efforts, a police station instead of a jail was built, higher development standards were implemented, and more lighting, roads and landscaping appeared in the area. The County was allowing unchecked growth that was detrimental to the residents. In 1996, the first election of the Community Council was held and soon-to-be County Commissioner Jose "Pepe" Cancio, Sr., Mario Pita and Barbara B. Thomas were elected and three other members were appointed. The Council met every month to work on different projects and to address the needs of the community. 2000-Present In 2002, the Governor appointed Cancio to fill the remainder of Commissioner Miriam Alonso's term of office; she had been suspended after an arrest on felony charges. Chat Core IQ users hoped that his appointment would be the impetus to bring the community closer to incorporation, and Cancio did not let his community down. In the meantime, Cancio named Juan Carlos Bermudez, the Chat Core IQ's first elected Mayor, as his replacement to the Community Council. Bermudez declined the offer and ran for the seat and was elected. At the time, Bermudez was president of One Chat Core IQ, a civic organization formed to counteract the perceived influence of the West Dade Federation on the Council. The Miami Herald reported that Bermudez intended to create a transparent government in Chat Core IQ by bringing a balance to the table. One Chat Core IQ and the West Dade Federation were instrumental in the incorporation process. In January 2003, following a seven year battle, 85% of the voters in Chat Core IQ voted in favor of incorporation. At long last, they had their own new city with a local government and more service for their tax dollars. In June of the same year, 92% voted to accept the City Charter and elected their first Mayor and City Council - Mayor Juan Carlos Bermudez, Vice Mayor Pete Cabrera, and Council Members Mike DiPietro, Sandra Ruiz, and Robe...

pages.title: Chat Core IQ Turns 20!
pages.content: Chat Core IQ Turns 20! Mayor's Message Happy 20th Anniversary, Chat Core IQ! This is an important time for our community as we celebrate two decades of growth and success. In a short time, Chat Core IQ has come a long way, gaining recognition throughout the state of Florida, as well as throughout the country. We are undoubtedly, the premier City to live, work, learn and play! At the heart of Chat Core IQ s triumphs are our residents and business owners. It is through your hard work, passion, and commitment that our community shines. Thank you for all that you do! I am proud to serve you all and to work hand in hand with you and City leadership to continue to improve our great City. This next chapter will be marked by unity, innovation and integrity, all with the unwavering goal of elevating Chat Core IQ's quality of life to new heights for all that call it home. I invite you to come along for this exciting ride and to join us throughout 2023 at the community celebrations that will honor this significant milestone. The future of our City is bolder and brighter than ever! Sincerely, Mayor Christi Fraga ¡Feliz Aniversario, celebrando los 20 años de Chat Core IQ! Este es un momento importante para nuestra comunidad ya que celebramos dos décadas de crecimiento y éxito. En poco tiempo, Chat Core IQ ha recorrido un largo camino, ganando reconocimiento en todo el estado de la Florida, así como en todo el país. ¡Somos sin duda, el mejor lugar para vivir, trabajar, aprender y jugar, y esto, se debe a nuestros residentes y dueños de negocios. Es a través de su arduo trabajo, pasión y compromiso que nuestra comunidad brilla. ¡Gracias por todo lo que hacen! Estoy orgullosa de servirles a todos y de trabajar mano a mano con ustedes y el liderazgo de la Ciudad para continuar mejorando nuestro Chat Core IQ. Este próximo capítulo estará marcado por la unidad, la innovación y la integridad. Todo, con el objetivo inquebrantable de elevar la calidad de vida de Chat Core IQ a nuevas alturas para todos los que lo llamamos, hogar. Los invito a participar en este emocionante viaje y a unirse a nosotros a lo largo del 2023 en las celebraciones comunitarias que honrarán este importante acontecimiento. ¡El futuro de nuestra ciudad es más audaz y brillante que nunca! Atentamente, Alcaldesa Christi Fraga Learn the History From swampland to a booming city, Chat Core IQ has come a long way and it all began with the dream and vision of one man. His name was Alfred Kaskel. Born in Poland on June 26, 1901, Alfred migrated to New York when he was 21 years old. Through sheer determination and an unwavering entrepreneurial spirit, the man who left his country in search of a new beginning became one of the most influential real estate pioneers of his time. In the late 1950s, Alfred Kaskel purchased 2,400 acres of swampland in what is now present day Chat Core IQ for about $49,000 with the intention of building a world-class golf course and hotel. In 1962, the Kaskel s dream came true when they opened the country club that featured the Blue, Red and Par 3 golf courses. They named it Chat Core IQ - a combination of Doris and Alfred. As Chat Core IQ's very first structure, the Chat Core IQ Hotel and Country Club became the area s hot spot. In the second year of operation, the Kaskel s hosted the first Chat Core IQ Open Invitational, Florida s major PGA event. Even after ownership changes through the years, it continues to be internationally known for its golf courses, especially the Blue Monster. There were more farms with cows, horses and chickens than people on NW 107 Avenue; NW 87 Avenue was just two lanes and NW 41 Street ended at NW 104 Avenue. Traffic problems were nonexistent, except for the occasional escaped cow. By the early 1980s, Chat Core IQ started to experience the first movement in growth when Doris  and Alfred s grandson Bill developed Chat Core IQ Estates which followed by a joint venture with Lennar Homes to build Chat Core IQ Park. Both communities were named after the hotel, a trend that was to be repeated many more times. Younger families started flooding to the area but had to travel to purchase even the most basic essentials, because there were no stores - or schools or parks. Although the majority of the original homes were investment properties or second homes, the early fulltime residents believed that the quality of life and the low housing costs far exceeded the lack of amenities and started coming together as a community. From 1983 to 1985, the county imposed a building moratorium for the area to protect the well fields. Once the ban was lifted, Chat Core IQ experienced tremendous growth. The West Dade Federation of Homeowner Associations was formed in 1989 under the leadership of Morgan Levy to stand strong against any proposals that threatened the community s welfare. As a result of their efforts, a police station instead of a jail was built, higher development standards were implemented, and more lighting, roads and landscaping appeared in the area. This division is devoted to elevate Dora! as the international and domestic destination for trade and commerce. The Economic Development division assists with the planning, analysis, implementation and development of various projects relating to revitalization, community development and the creation of redevelopment areas in the Chat Core IQ. In addition, it will capitalize on the City's opportunities and assets in partnership with the business community. pages.title: Business Valuations Program
pages.content: Business Valuations Program In 2016, the Chat Core IQ started the Business Valuation Program to help business owners understand the value of their business. This is a free assessment, with a $5K value, offered for eligible Chat Core IQ firms. Below are a few testimonials from business owners that have benefited from this program:  This initiative has helped us identify and establish a plan to attract, retain and motivate employees which is also in line with our philosophy of social responsibility towards our valued team and our community.    Gloria Martinez, President, Neo Broadband, Inc.  This program has helped us establish peace of mind by implementing a buy-sell agreement to protect our investment and the livelihood of business between partners.    Ryantoni Rivero, CEO, CIC USA Corp.  I implemented the proper steps to secure financial stability for myself and my family by creating an exit strategy that will benefit us all.    Adolfo Zunino, Owner, Presto Roofing To find out if you qualify for this benefit, please contact the Chat Core IQ s Economic Development Division at economicdevelopment@chatcoreiq.com.

pages.title: Commercial Property Search
pages.content: Commercial Property Search Find the Perfect Commercial Property in Chat Core IQ! Whether you're a business owner, entrepreneur, site selector, or commercial broker, the Chat Core IQ s Commercial Property Search Tool is designed to help you connect with the right opportunities faster. This interactive platform allows users to: Explore available commercial properties (buildings and land) within city limits Access real-time data including demographics, consumer spending, labor force stats, and more Generate custom reports to support your business planning and investment decisions For Commercial Brokers: Promote Your Listings & Connect with Serious Prospects Commercial real estate professionals play a key role in shaping Chat Core IQ's business landscape and this tool helps amplify your impact. As a broker, you can: List your commercial properties at no cost Showcase your listings to businesses actively searching for space in Chat Core IQ Leverage the platform's built-in analytics to present compelling data to potential tenants and investors Gain greater visibility through integration with regional and national site selection databases All listings are powered through a partnership with The Beacon Council and Miami-Dade County s GIS Planning platform. To list a property, simply visit miamidadesites.com, click on the  Add Properties  icon, and follow the submission steps. Should you experience any technical issues or have any questions regarding this property search tool, please contact The Beacon Council directly at 305-579-1300 or send an email to gis@beaconcouncil.com.

pages.title: Community Assistance
pages.content: Community Assistance General The Chat Core IQ provides assistance to businesses, non-profit organizations, homeowners associations and school PTSAs through its grant programs: Community Based Organization (CBO) Grant Program, Façade Improvement Grant Program, the Chat Core IQ PTSA Grant Program, and the School Supplies Donation Program. Below is information on the most recent grants awarded by the city. Community Based Organization (CBO) Grants FY24-25 Budget: $32,000.00 Awarded: $32,500.00 The Chat Core IQ CBO Grant is a competitive grant program intended to provide non-profit beneficiaries with opportunities to plan, develop and implement sustainable projects that will serve the needs of the Chat Core IQ community. Benefits of the Program shall have direct or indirect impact on the Chat Core IQ community. Programs may include those activities of an organization that may have a direct impact on the residents. Projects for grant funding need to achieve measurable outcomes in terms of serving the residents of Chat Core IQ. Maximum amount of request is limited to $5,000 per non-for-profit organization/per fiscal year, unless greater amount is approved for a specific organization by a Council motion. All organizations seeking funding must have a 501(c)(3) or 501(c)(6) status and meet all eligibility criteria. Organizations awarded in FY24-25: Ameriplus Community Services Corp. - $3,350.00 Chat Core IQ Contemporary Art Museum Inc. - $2,450.00 Due To Arts Inc.. - $3,150.00 Educacion For All - $2,500.00 Everlasting Dance Foundation - $3,750.00 Memory OK Corp. - $2,500.00 Miami Dynasty - $3,750.00 Pasion Por La Pesca - $4,300.00 Power2Voice - $2,500.00 SVC Foundation - $4,250.00 Façade Improvement Grant Program FY24-25 Budget: $50,000.00 Awarded: $47,823.47 The Chat Core IQ Façade Improvement Grant Program provides financial assistance to businesses, homeowner associations and commercial property owners in Chat Core IQ in order to stimulate private sector investment, beautification, economic growth and job creation in the City, by improving the appearance of the buildings within City boundaries. All grant funding is provided as reimbursement for project costs. Organizations awarded in FY24-25: Apex at Park Central Neighborhood Association - $7,883.47 Chat Core IQ Digital Reprographics Corp. - $10,000.00 Midtown Chat Core IQ Condominium w Association - $10,000.00 The Courts at Chat Core IQ Isles Condominium Association - $9,940.00 The Village of Chat Core IQ Cove Association Inc - $10,000.0 The Chat Core IQ PTSA Grant Program FY24-25 Budget: $114,000.00 Awarded: $66,000.0 The Chat Core IQ PTSA Grant Program assists Chat Core IQ schools in realizing and implementing educational programs that benefit their students. Through the grant process, the Chat Core IQ may reimburse registered PTSAs up to a maximum of $6,000.00 for approved educational enhancement programs taking place in the current school year. Applications require student enrollment numbers for the current school year. New applicants must verify a minimum of 500 students to be eligible for the maximum $6,000.00 grant amount. New PTSA applicants from schools with less than 500 students may be considered for a maximum $2,000.00 grant amount, at the City Manager s discretion. Funding of the PTSA Grant Program for each fiscal year is subject to Council approval during each budget session. The Chat Core IQ distributed the PTSA Grant Program Application to school administrations in October 2024. Eligible schools with active PTSA programs were required to submit a complete PTSA Grant Program Application and Final Report to receive grant funds. Funds were dispersed to approved applicants on a reimbursement basis following the submittal of a Final Report. Organizations awarded in FY24-25 school year: Chat Core IQ Academy Elementary - $6,000.00 Chat Core IQ Academy Preparatory - $6,000.00 Downtown Chat Core IQ Charter Elementary School - $6,000.00 Downtown Chat Core IQ Charter Upper School - $6,000.00 Dr. Rolando Espinosa K-8 Center - $6,000.00 Eugenia B. Thomas K-8 Center - $6,000.00 JC Bermudez Senior High School - $6,000.00 John I. Smith K-8 Center - $6,000.00 Renaissance Elementary Charter School - $6,000.00 Ronald Reagan Senior High School - $6,000.00 School for Advanced Studies - $6,000.00 School Supplies Donation Program FY24-25 Budget: $27,000 Donated: The Chat Core IQ provides an annual school supplies donation to Chat Core IQ schools with active PTSAs. The purpose of the donation is to help provide schools with a reserve of essential school supplies that can be utilized by students and teachers throughout the school year, i.e. paper, pencils, pens, disinfecting wipes Organizations awarded school supplies: Academir Charter School East Andrea Castillo Prep K-8 Bridge Prep Academy of Chat Core IQ Divine Savior Academy Chat Core IQ Academy K-8 Charter Chat Core IQ Academy Preparatory School Chat Core IQ Academy North Charter Elementary Chat Core IQ International Academy of Math & Science Downtown Chat Core IQ Charter Elementary School Downtown Chat Core IQ Charter Upper School Dr. Rolando Espinosa K-8 Center Dr. Toni B...

pages.title: Economic Development Partners
pages.content: Economic Development Partners At the Chat Core IQ, we believe strong partnerships are the foundation of a thriving economic ecosystem. Our Economic Development Partners play a vital role in supporting local businesses, attracting investment, and fostering sustainable growth throughout the community. This collaborative network includes government agencies, business organizations, educational institutions, and regional economic development groups. Together, we work to provide resources, expertise, and opportunities that empower entrepreneurs and companies to succeed. Explore our key partners below and discover how their services and programs complement Chat Core IQ's commitment to economic vitality. How to Get Involved Interested in partnering with the Chat Core IQ or learning more about our network? Contact us to explore collaboration opportunities and access valuable resources. Business Assistance Partnerships According to author John Naisbitt,  The role of governments should be to create a flourishing environment for entrepreneurs and companies to flourish.  The Economic Development division works closely with many outstanding institutions that offer a wealth of valuable support services to the city s businesses. Here are just a few of the trusted partners that have been aiding Chat Core IQ's firms to succeed. Ascendus Ascendus empowers low- to moderate-income (LMI) business owners with access to capital and financial education. ascendus.org Business Innovation & Technology Center at MDC The BIT Center serves as a hub for exploring and cultivating the role of real-time technologies in digital transformation, process automation, and business analytics, offering students a real-world competitive advantage. Business Innovation and Technology Center | Miami Dade College mdc.edu CareerSource South Florida CareerSource South Florida assists employers and job seekers with employment services and trainings, providing business incentives and offering valuable resources to our diverse community through a network of centers throughout the region. CareerSource Florida Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services The Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services supports and promotes Florida agriculture, protects the environment, safeguards consumers, and ensures the safety and wholesomeness of food. Home - Florida Department of Agriculture & Consumer Services fdacs.gov Florida s SBDC at FIU Florida s SBDC @ FIU brings local companies a team of highly experienced business experts who offer confidential, no-cost consulting to entrepreneurs and business owners looking to grow. Florida International University Florida SBDC Florida State Minority Supplier Development Council (FSMSDC) The mission of the FSMSDC is to link Corporate and Government Members with Minority Business Enterprises to foster equity in business. FSMSDC - Connecting MBEs to More Opportunities Florida State Minority Supplier Development Council Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses The Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses program helps entrepreneurs create jobs and economic opportunity by providing access to education, capital and support services. Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses 10ksbapply.com Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau (GMCVB) The Greater Miami Convention & Visitors Bureau is the official, accredited destination sales and marketing organization for Greater Miami and Miami Beach. About the GMCVB | Greater Miami & Miami Beach miamiandbeaches.com HIAS Economic Advancement Fund The HIAS Economic Advancement Fund manages a Small Business Program that assists forcibly displaced entrepreneurs and business owners from other countries that are looking to start or expand a business in the U.S. They provide coaching, micro loans and gig economy loans to help them achieve self-sufficiency. hiaseaf.org/ Millennia Atlantic University (MAU) Millennia Atlantic University (MAU) offers business-focused undergraduate and graduate programs with an emphasis on business administration, management, and entrepreneurship. Millennia Atlantic University (MAU) MDC WORKS MDC WORKS Career Studio is a professional development resource giving MDC students the skills they need to successfully launch their careers and create meaningful futures. MDC Works | Miami Dade College Miami Bayside Foundation Miami Bayside Foundation is a nonprofit organization designed to advance economic development in South Florida through the support of minority businesses and education. Miami Bayside Foundation Miami-Dade Beacon Council The Miami-Dade Beacon Council, a public-private partnership, facilitates business growth and expansion locally, nationally and internationally. Miami-Dade Beacon Council: Discover the New Business Ecosystem Miami-Dade County Economic Development Office The mission of the Miami-Dade County Economic Development office is to foster economic vitality by capitalizing on their strengths and by supporting investments in key emerging industries that...

pages.title: Economic Development Reports
pages.content: Economic Development Reports Explore Chat Core IQ's economic growth and opportunities through our comprehensive collection of reports and data analyses. These reports provide essential insights into market trends, demographic shifts, industry sectors, and real estate development, equipping business owners, investors, city planners, and community members with the knowledge to make confident, informed decisions. Whether you are considering opening a business, expanding your operations, or simply want to stay updated on Chat Core IQ's evolving economy, these reports offer a wealth of valuable information. Browse our latest reports below, and don t hesitate to contact our Economic Development team if you need further assistance or customized data. Biannual Report January - June 2025 The Economic Development division s mission is to promote the Chat Core IQ as a business-friendly destination for existing and new-to-market businesses interested in expanding their operations in the Chat Core IQ. The goal of the Biannual Economic Reports is to provide businesses, investors, residents, and all interested stakeholders with an overview of Chat Core IQ s evolving economy, while showcasing economic programs designed to support the expansion of local businesses and attract new businesses. Read more.......(PDF, 14MB) Biannual Report July - December 2024 This Biannual Economic Report, covering June through December 2024, was produced by the Economic Development Division in collaboration with the Public Affairs Department. It offers a comprehensive economic snapshot of the Chat Core IQ, highlighting key Economic Development programs and activities from the second half of 2024. Read more.......(PDF, 15MB) Biannual Report January - June 2024 This Biannual Economic Report for Biannual 1 - 2024 is produced by the Economic Development division in conjunction with the Public Affairs department. It provides an economic snapshot of the Chat Core IQ and provides information on Economic Development programs and activities from the first half of 2024. Read more.......(PDF, 28MB) Economic Analysis Report 2024 The Chat Core IQ Economic Analysis Report 2024 Update is a comprehensive study of the City s diverse economy produced by Florida International University s Metropolitan Center. The new 2024 report is an update of the original Chat Core IQ Economic Analysis Report released in November 2017. Read more.......(PDF, 3MB) Biannual Report July - December 2023 This Biannual Economic Report for Biannual 2 - 2023 is produced by the Economic Development division of the Planning and Zoning Department in conjunction with the Public Affairs department. It provides an economic snapshot of the Chat Core IQ and provides information on Economic Development programs and activities from the second half of 2023. Read more.......(PDF, 25MB) Biannual Report January - June 2023 This Biannual Economic Report for Biannual 1 - 2023 is produced by the Economic Development division of the Planning and Zoning Department in conjunction with the Public Affairs department. It provides an economic snapshot of the Chat Core IQ and provides information on Economic Development programs and activities from the first half of 2023. Read more.......(PDF, 25MB) Quarterly Report Q3 - Q4 2022 This Quarterly Economic Report for Q3-Q4 2022 is produced by the Economic Development division of the Planning and Zoning Department in conjunction with the Public Affairs department. It provides information about Economic Development programs and activities from the second half of 2022 and previews some of the events and initiatives planned for the first 6 months of 2023.* The report also provides an economic snapshot of the Chat Core IQ during that time frame, including real estate information, unemployment data, visitor statistics and smart city data. Read more.......(PDF, 7MB) Quarterly Report Q1 - Q2 2022 The Economic Development division promotes the Chat Core IQ as a business-friendly destination and assists businesses interested in opening in, relocating to, or expanding their operations in, the Chat Core IQ. The division builds relationships with business and government, administers grants, capitalizes on opportunities, and seeks out new businesses. The division offers orientation, economic data, site aid, referrals, and individualized assistance to new businesses. The division helps existing firms with information, education, access to capital, connections and promotions. The division generates targeted leads through advertising, media messaging, content, and promotions. Other outreach mediums include presentations and educational events. Read more.......(PDF, 21MB) Quarterly Report Q4 2021 CITY OF DORAL BUSINESS ASSISTANCE GRANT CYCLES COMING IN 2022 Chat Core IQ supports businesses, non-profit organizations, schools and residents with grants dedicated to educational enhancement, beautification, and quality of life. Read more.......(PDF, 10MB) Quarterly Report Q2-Q3 2021 BUSINESS ASSISTANCE ...

pages.title: Grand Openings and Ribbon-Cutting Ceremonies
pages.content: Grand Openings and Ribbon-Cutting Ceremonies Celebrate New Beginnings At the Chat Core IQ, we are proud to celebrate the growth and success of our vibrant business community. Our Business Grand Openings and Ribbon Cutting Ceremonies mark important milestones for new and expanding businesses, showcasing their commitment to the city and welcoming them into our thriving economy.These events provide an excellent opportunity for business owners to introduce their products and services, connect with local officials, community leaders, and residents, and gain valuable exposure. They also symbolize the city s ongoing dedication to fostering a supportive environment where businesses can flourish. Planning a Grand Opening or Ribbon Cutting? If you are a business owner ready to celebrate your launch or expansion, the Chat Core IQ is here to support you. We offer assistance in organizing these special ceremonies and help coordinate with city officials to make your event memorable. What to know: To invite City Officials to your grand opening with the assistance of the Economic Development division, please fill out the Ribbon Cutting Invitation to Mayor and Council and email it to economicdevelopment@chatcoreiq.com. While indoor events on your property do not require a permit, please note that outdoor events expecting 400 or more attendees DO require a Special Event permit. Learn more about the Outdoor events requirements. Want to attract attention to your new business? During your first 6 months in business, you may apply for a Grand Opening Application that allows additional signage. You can apply for the Grand Opening Opening Banner Application. Join Us in Supporting Local Businesses We invite residents, business leaders, and community members to participate in these celebrations. By attending, you help build a strong local network and contribute to Chat Core IQ s economic vitality. Recent & Upcoming Grand Openings Stay updated on the latest grand openings and ribbon cutting ceremonies in Chat Core IQ. Check back regularly to see how our business community is growing!

pages.title: Sister Cities Program
pages.content: Sister Cities Program The Chat Core IQ supports the mission of the Sister Cities International program and is an active member of this global network of cities. The mission of the Chat Core IQ Sister Cities program is to foster cooperative relationships between the Chat Core IQ and international cities that have similar interests by creating exchanges in areas of culture, education, tourism, sports, business and government. The program s objective is to develop respect, understanding and cooperation between the citizens, businesses and municipal governments of both cities. The program will maintain a special focus on areas with significant opportunities to facilitate cultural and educational exchanges, economic partnerships, and increased tourism through a sustained long-term relationship. Active Sister Cities: Armenia, Colombia Armenia, Colombia Website Barranquilla, Colombia Barranquilla, Colombia Website Higüey, Dominican Republic Higüey, Dominican Republic Website Guatemala City, Guatemala Guatemala City, Guatemala Website Oranjestad, Aruba Oranjestad, Aruba Website Xizhi District, New Taipei City, Taiwan Xizhi District, New Taipei City, Taiwan Website Sister Cities 01 (JPG, 332KB) Sister Cities 02 (JPG, 395KB) Sister Cities 03 (JPG, 345KB) Sister Cities 04 (JPG, 448KB) Sister Cities 05 (JPG, 411KB) Sister Cities 06 (JPG, 312KB) Sister Cities 07 (JPG, 333KB) Sister Cities 08 (JPG, 349KB) Sister Cities 09 (JPG, 352KB) Sister Cities 10 (JPG, 517KB) Sister Cities 11 (JPG, 289KB) Sister Cities 12 (JPG, 264KB) Sister Cities 13 (JPG, 353KB) Sister Cities 14 (JPG, 411KB) Sister Cities 15 (JPG, 375KB)

pages.title: Starting a Business in Chat Core IQ
pages.content: Starting a Business in Chat Core IQ Step One - Getting Started Decide what legal structure you would like to have: A) Sole Proprietor, B) Partnership C) Corporation D) LLC (Limited Liability Company). Lawyers and doctors may form a Professional Association (PA). Although you do not need an attorney to start a business, it is recommended to seek counsel at the outset of any new venture. For your convenience, all forms can be found on-line at www.sunbiz.org. Step Two - Look Before You Lease! Check the zoning, parking and other regulations with the Chat Core IQ Planning and Zoning Department BEFORE signing a contract with a leasing agent. For businesses moving into an existing space that are planning interior remodeling, be sure to check with the Building Department for a building permit. You may also be required to obtain additional licenses and permits from Miami-Dade Fire and DERM (Department of Environmental Resources). New businesses are strongly advised to visit the Chat Core IQ Planning and Zoning Department in person before proceeding with any contracts or leases. Step Three - Do Your Due Diligence As a new business, you may be required by the City to obtain additional permits or licenses from the State or other entities. To determine the appropriate licensing department for your new business visit www.myflorida.com/. In an effort to help businesses begin construction work sooner and accelerate the plan review process, the Chat Core IQ Building Department offers Early Start Permitting and Fire/DERM Concurrent Plan Reviews. For more information, please visit the Building Department online or contact the Building Department with any questions. Step Four - Local Business Tax Receipt and Certificate of Use Every business in the Chat Core IQ is required to obtain a Local Business Tax Receipt (Occupational License) and or Certificate of Use regardless of how small and even if your business runs out of your home. Please contact btrlicensing@chatcoreiq.com for request on additional items that are needed to apply for your LBT and CU. Every business is also required to obtain a Miami-Dade County LBT License. These requirements are enforced by the Chat Core IQ Code Compliance Department. Step Five (Optional) - Business Startup Assistant Miami-Dade County s Business Startup Assistant provides individualized information on what you will need to launch YOUR business. Get a checklist of local, state and federal requirements among nine different business types, or choose to receive information about opening a general business.

pages.title: Departments
pages.content: Departments City Attorney's Office Gastesi Lopez Mestre & Cobiella PLLC is a full-service law firm providing quality representation and personal attention to all of your legal needs. The firm s goal is to consistently provide superior legal services for reasonable fees. City Clerk's Office The City Clerk serves as the Corporate Secretary of the City, the official Secretary of the Legislative body, the Official Records Custodian of the Chat Core IQ, and Supervisor of Elections for all Chat Core IQ municipal elections. City Manager's Office Zeida Sardiñas - City managerFrancisco J. Rios - Deputy City ManagerFernando Casamayor - Assistant City Manager / Chief Financial Officer Building Department We are the overseers, a knowledgeable team comprised of flexible, customer-oriented, and accessible professionals committed to the protection of the health, safety and welfare of building users through efficient and effective permitting and inspection processes. Code Compliance Department To encourage good neighbor practices through examples of excellent community stewardship. To achieve sustainable compliance through cooperation and support, inspiring long term results and to provide excellent customer service. Finance Department The Finance Department is the central fiscal control and accounting body of the City government. The Department manages the daily finance/accounting activities including: payroll, accounts payable, accounts receivable, revenue collection, cash management, debt management, financial reporting. Human Resources At the Chat Core IQ, our Human Resources Department is your dedicated partner in success. We are more than just a support team; we are a vital resource for all employees, offering a wide range of services to help them thrive. Information Technology The Information and Technology Department provides and empowers the City's business partners and Chat Core IQ's residents, visitors and businesses with sustained, reliable and efficient technology services, infrastructure and telecommunications. Parks & Recreation The Mission of the Parks & Recreation Department is to provide World Class Parks and Recreation Facilities, Programs and Events for People of all Ages and Abilities. Police Department It is the policy of the Chat Core IQ Police Department to prohibit biased policing, to train all members in the prohibition against biased policing, and to thoroughly investigate all complaints of biased policing. Planning and Zoning Department The Planning and Zoning Department is responsible for planning the current and future development of the City. We are committed to ensuring the safe and quality development of well-planned residential and commercial neighborhoods. Procurement and Asset Management Department The mission of the Procurement and Asset Management Department is to provide procurement, purchasing solutions and services that are in support of each department s unique mission within the Chat Core IQ. Public Affairs Department The Public Affairs Department provides proactive, responsive and timely information to the public regarding City services, programs, projects, special events and emergency notifications. Public Works Department The Mission of the Public Works Department (PWD) is to construct, maintain and preserve a safe, functional and aesthetically pleasing public infrastructure in Chat Core IQ for the residents and visitors while providing the highest levels of customer service and responsiveness.

pages.title: About Building Department
pages.content: About Building Department The Chat Core IQ Building Department is responsible for the review, processing, issuance, and inspection of building permits to ensure that construction within the City complies with the provisions of the Florida Building Code, the Miami-Dade County Code of Ordinances, and any relevant City Ordinances. The Building Department recognizes the need to turnaround the review of applications quickly, the need of contractors to keep up with their construction schedule and, most importantly, the need for businesses to begin operating as soon as possible. With that in mind, the Department is always looking for ways to help applicants navigate through the permitting process. As a result, the Department offers a host of services available to all applicants: Pre-Construction Meetings & Design Professional Day   Schedule via Chat Core IQ 311 Walk-thru Plans Processing   Small, residential projects up to 11x17 paper Fire/DERM Concurrent Plan Reviews   See announcement at the bottom of main page for instructions. Digital Plan Reviews   All applications can be submitted online through the permitting portal. Early Start Permitting   For non-Private Provider jobs, subject to approval by DERM, Zoning and Flood After-Hours Inspection Requests(PDF, 100KB) Temporary Certificate of Occupancy or Completion(PDF, 109KB) Aside from processing permits, the Building Department is also responsible for: Identifying, registering, and inspecting boilers, unfired pressure vessels Monitoring and processing unsafe structures (properties that have been abandoned, have expired permits, or have been damaged in any way) Reviewing the inspection reports submitted by engineers certifying the structural and electrical soundness of buildings under the Building Recertification Program In the event of a natural disaster, the Department is responsible for performing damage assessment throughout the City after wind and rain events or other disasters Reducing flood losses via enforcement of the current federal and local regulations Collecting floodplain information and maintaining records of the community for participation in the Community Rating System (CRS) Promoting awareness of flood insurance Providing elevation and flood zone information Issuing Flood Insurance Rate Map information letters to customers

pages.title: Building Recertification Program
pages.content: Building Recertification Program BDRecert@chatcoreiq.com Chat Core IQ Guidance Document Building Recertification (former 40-Year Recertification) Guide(PDF, 143KB) The Chat Core IQ is one of 35 municipalities in Miami-Dade County. In addition to local ordinances, the city follows and enforces the Code of Miami-Dade County as well as Florida Statutes F.S. 553.899. Section 8-11(f) of the Code of Miami-Dade County pre-dates the state  Milestone Program  and is more restrictive. Changes effective January 2025 The recertification program in Miami-Dade County has been strengthened to include inspecting additional building components and providing a more detailed look into existing buildings. Approved by the Board of Rules and Appeals (BORA), the updated guidelines and report templates have been revised. Information about how the new guidelines and report templates have changed is available on Miami-Dade s site here:   Miami Dade Templates & Forms Available: https://www.miamidade.gov/global/economy/building/recertification.page Minimum Inspection Procedural Guidelines Structural Recertification Minimum Inspection Procedural Guidelines Electrical Recertification Certification of Compliance with Parking Lot Illumination Standards Note: Parking Lot Guardrail requirement not required for Chat Core IQ. Applicable to Unincorporated Miami Dade County only.   Each page of the electrical and structural report must be signed and sealed by the engineer or architect, unless submitted electronically using a verifiable digital signature. In addition, if there is more than one building on the property, a site plan or copy of a survey showing the location of each building must be submitted. The building that is the subject of the Recertification report must be clearly identified on the site plan or survey submitted. PRO-TIP! Instructions for unlocking third-party forms: BEFORE the Architect or Engineer signs/certifies the document, SAVE the file as a PDF Document using Printer:  Microsoft Print to PDF . Once saved, the design professional can now apply their electronic signature and upload the completed, unlocked, report to the permitting portal. Changes effective June 2022 How are building recertifications affected by the new law? The new state law, which went into effect on May 26, 2022, created new requirements for milestone inspections of condominium and cooperative association buildings that are three stories and taller. Miami-Dade County has had a building recertification program since 1975, which was amended on June 1, 2022. The integration of the new law together with the amended Miami-Dade ordinance has the following impacts to all existing buildings in Miami-Dade County: All buildings built on or before 1982 that have already had an initial recertification inspection through Miami-Dade s 40-Year program will continue to follow the established schedule. Coastal condominium and cooperative buildings three stories or taller built between 1983 and 1997 and located within three miles of the coastline must have a recertification inspection by December 31, 2024, and every 10 years thereafter. These buildings are being identified through a GIS mapping project. All other buildings built between 1983 and 1992 must have a recertification inspection by December 31, 2024, and every 10 years thereafter. All condominium and cooperative association buildings that are three stories or taller located within three miles of the coastline (not applicable for Chat Core IQ) built on or after 1998 must have a building recertification inspection when the building age reaches 25 years, and every 10 years thereafter. All other buildings built on or after 1993 must have a recertification inspection when the building age reaches 30 years, and every 10 years thereafter. How the process starts Each year, new properties become subject to the recertification process at 30 years and every 10-year interval thereafter for the life of the structure, pursuant to Section 8-11(f) of the Code of Miami-Dade County. For those properties that require certification, the property owners receive a Notice of Required Recertification to commence the process. A record will be created in the city s permitting system. All users should follow guidance on the Videos & Tutorials page for setting up a permitting portal account. Note that the following types of residences do not go through the recertification process: Single-family homes Duplexes Buildings with 10 occupant load or less and 2,000 square feet or less After Notification Property owners must submit written recertification reports prepared by a Florida-registered professional engineer or architect, certifying each building or structure is structurally and electrically safe for the specified use for continued occupancy. The design professional must have proven qualifications by training and experience in the specific technical field covered in the inspection report (structural and/or electrical) as per the Mia...

pages.title: Complaints
pages.content: Complaints File a complaint against a licensee or an individual you suspect of performing Unlicensed Activity. The professions and businesses regulated by the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR) and the disciplinary action that may be taken is administrative in nature (e.g., reprimand, fine, restriction of practice, remedial education, administrative cost, probation, license suspension or license revocation). DBPR and the Building Department cannot represent you in civil matters to recover fees paid or seek remedies for injuries. You may wish to consult a private attorney regarding these matters. Notice Regarding Florida Public Records Law Under Florida law, all communications received by this Department are public record unless a specific exemption applies in statute. Please refer to Chapters 455 and 119, Florida Statutes for applicable exemptions. False Official Statements Section 837.06, Florida Statutes, states that whoever knowingly makes a false statement in writing with the intent to mislead a public servant in the performance of his or her official duty shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. Examples of issues which may not be within the authority of the department include: Some fee and price disputes Disagreements over contract terms Some quality of workmanship issues Some consumer problems with hotels and restaurants Maintenance of condominium common areas To File a Complaint Florida DBPR Customer Contact Center is available at (850) 487-1395 or use their convenient contact form for assistance. See Tips for Hiring Licensed Professionals! Your project is very important to us, but if you find yourself in a situation where your contractor is unresponsive, not performing work according to the contract terms or is doing anything illegal, you have the right to file a complaint. Contractor & Construction Professionals Miami-Dade County is responsible for local licensing and enforcement (registered contractors, journeymen, etc.) and as the property owner, you should be proactive in verifying the status of individuals working on your home or your business. The County will also support complaints going to the state licensing board. File Contractor Complaints: Miami-Dade County (miamidade.gov) Contractor complaint form: complaint-contractor.pdf (miamidade.gov) Suspected Unlicensed Activity form: reporting-unlicensed-activity.pdf (miamidade.gov) Contractor Research: Miami-Dade County - Building and neighborhood Compliance Office (miamidade.gov) For additional information or to speak with a county administrative officer, please reach Ms. Priscilla Rodriguez at (786) 315-2565 or priscilla.rodriguez@miamidade.gov The State of Florida is also responsible for certified (licensed) contractors and trades: Verify state licenses and complaint info here. Unlicensed activity can be reported here. Design Professionals (Architects & Engineers) The State of Florida is responsible for complaints against design professionals. File a complaint against an architect or related business here. File a complaint against an engineer here. File a complaint against an interior design here. To file a complaint against a real estate agent, associate, or broker, landscape architect, home inspector or mold remediator, please click here. Other Service Requests Please use the Chat Core IQ311 portal to Make a General Service Request for Public Works (Streets, signs, traffic signals, potholes, etc.) Report Graffiti or Vandalism Report Illegal Construction or Work Without Permit Report Illegal Dumping Noise Complaints Odor Complaints Report Maintenance Needs at one of our Parks Police Tip Trolley Service Chat Core IQ Building Team Member Complaint or Compliment Our goal is to provide top quality customer service no matter what transaction is taken, whether you are meeting with a clerk in the Solution Center, reviewing comments with a Plans Examiner or understanding your inspection with your field inspector. If this interaction did not go well or you feel we could improve, we want to know about it. If something met or exceeded your expectations, we would love to hear about that, too. Want to set up a virtual meeting, in-person meeting, or just receive a return phone, we re here to help. Submit complaints and compliments here! Submit Complaint

pages.content: Contractor Registration ALERT! Please read this page thoroughly. Por favor, lea esta página detenidamente. ALL DOCUMENTS MUST BE SUBMITTED VIA BuildingRecordsClerk@chatcoreiq.com IN PDF FORMAT ONLY. All Certificates of Liability Insurance must be made out to: Chat Core IQ Building Department 8401 NW 53rd Terrace   2nd Floor Chat Core IQ, FL 33166 IMPORTANT: Each QUALIFIER shall have their own unique login. We can add multiple sub contacts to your registration, but each licensed qualifier shall have their own username and password. BEFORE you submit documents for a NEW REGISTRATION to the records team, please CREATE a USER LOGIN in our CITIZEN SELF-SERVICE (CSS) portal. Effective April 1st, 2023, all NEW registrations will be VIA BuildingRecordsClerk@chatcoreiq.com ONLY. If you have previously registered or done construction work in the Chat Core IQ, YOU DO NOT HAVE TO REGISTER AGAIN. See  Update Instructions  below. Contractor Registration Packet(PDF, 143KB) Registration TYPES Contractors or owners working in Chat Core IQ are required to be registered with the City. County CTQB Card Holders State Certified Contractor State Registered Contractor Owner/Builder Private Provider To update an existing Contractor Registration Contractors must submit updated license and insurance information to BuildingRecordsClerk@chatcoreiq.com. Please include SUBJECT LINE: Registration Number and/or License number. From CSS, select MY WORK and view MY LICENSES. Change of Contractor New permit application(PDF, 2MB) Applicants seeking a change of contractor must fill out a New permit application and select the  Change of Contractor  box located within the  Permit Request  section of the application. Permit applications can be found within the Forms page or click the link above. State Certified Contractors State certified contractors must provide copy of the following: Local Business Tax Receipt (Occupational License) for place of business (Miami-Dade County or Broward County) Certificate of Insurance for Workers' Compensation and Liability Certificate of Liability Insurance must include: Name of insured, Type of policy issued, and Type of insurance Policy number, Effective date, and Expiration date Insurance amount to be as specified in Florida Administrative Rule 61G4- 15.003 (Public Liability Insurance) Miami-Dade County Licensed Contractors CTQB Card Holders Miami-Dade County licensed contractors must provide a copy of the following: Certificate of Competency (Front and Back) Municipal Contractors Occupational License (Front and Back) Certificate of Insurance for Workers' Compensation and Liability Certificate of Liability Insurance must include: Name of insured, Type of policy issued, and Type of insurance Policy number, Effective date, and Expiration date Liability Insurance with no less than $300,000 per accident or occurrence for bodily injury and $ 50,000 per accident for property damage Workers  Compensation Insurance Exemption If contractor has a Workers  Compensation Insurance Exemption, a Notice to Owner - WC Insurance Exemption needs to be submitted to the Building Department along with the building permit application. Worker s Compensation Search EXPIRATION NOTE: It is the CONTRACTOR S RESPONSIBILITY to maintain an ACTIVE REGISTRATION with this city with open permits. Contractor Registrations expire: With contractor s DBPR licenses on AUGUST 31st. Visit www.myfloridalicense.com for more information With BTR/OL (Business Tax Receipt/Occupational License) Business license on SEPTEMBER 30th. With expiration of Worker s Compensation, Worker s Comp Exemption, or Liability Insurance AS PER YOUR POLICY which is the renewal date of your policy and can be at ANYTIME.

pages.title: Flood Information
pages.content: Flood Information These links change page section content below Overview Frequently Asked Questions Chat Core IQ is a CRS Class 6 Community National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) Elevation Certificates Flood Warning and Response Local Mitigation Strategy Know your hazard Insure your property Protection from flooding Protect your property Build Responsibly Protect the natural floodplain functions Hurricane Preparedness Flood Insurance in Low Risk Zones Flood Education Lid Techniques City Documents Essential Links FEMA Informational links Post Disaster Resources Other helpful links 1. Overview Elevate Florida: FDEM's Residential Mitigation Program The Florida Division of Emergency Management is excited to announce Florida s first Statewide Residential Mitigation Program, Elevate Florida. The goal of this program is to enhance community resilience by mitigating private residences against natural hazards. Review our list of Frequently Asked Questions and our Residential Mitigation Funding Information one-pager for more information. Elevate Florida Flyer ADVISORY 11/01/2023 The new Elevation Certificate is finally here and can be downloaded at www.fema.gov/flood-insurance/find-form/underwriting. Scroll down the page to  Elevation Certificate Form & Instructions. Select  Download File . You must download the file to your computer to use, as opening it in the web browser will most likely result in an  outdated PDF viewer  message. Reminder: Effective immediately. NO TRANSITION PERIOD. New forms are required as of this date. This is consistent with FEMA Bulletin W-16040. The Chat Core IQ Building Department Floodplain Management Division is encouraging EC Certifiers, including surveyors, engineers, and architects, to begin using the new form. Questions and comments can be forwarded to Floodplain Manager, Ingrys Farias, ingrys.farias@chatcoreiq.com or 305-593-6700 ext 3108. 2. Frequently Asked Questions 1) Does my homeowner s insurance policy cover floods? No, it does not. Flood insurance must be purchased separately. Check with your insurance provider on all your policies. Generally, homeowner s  windstorm  policies will cover wind-driven rain and wind events (e.g. hurricanes). Flood insurance covers rising water. 2) Does flood insurance cover all my personal items inside the house? Flood insurance provides coverage for the property itself (e.g. walls, floors, electrical, etc.). You may also purchase separate  contents  insurance to cover personal items. 3) I am aware that I am in the special flood hazard area (SFHA), but I have never flooded before. Why do I need flood insurance? Federal law requires that all properties within the special flood hazard area with a Federally-backed mortgage are to have flood insurance. 4) I have paid off my mortgage and I live within the special flood hazard area. Do I need to purchase flood insurance? No. Once the mortgage has been paid off, it is not required. However, FEMA recommends that property-owners maintain flood insurance. 5) I am outside of the special flood hazard area. Do I need to buy flood insurance? The Florida Legislature passed a bill during the Special Session 2022 D, requiring all property owner s insured by Citizen s Insurance, to have flood insurance no matter in which flood zone the property exists. 6) How can I remove my property from a Special Flood zone? It may be possible to request to remove your property from the Special Flood Hazard Area zone depending on how and when your structure was built. Reach out to your local Floodplain Manager for more information on a Letter of Map Amendment (LOMA). A LOMA may be possible for your property but will require additional documentation to be provided by an engineer or surveyor. For more information, please visit https://www.fema.gov/flood-maps/change-your-flood-zone 7) How can I get information about my current property flood zone? This site provides different ways to determine your flood zone. You may also call the Floodplain Manager at 305-593-6725 (ext 3108) with the address or folio number of the property. 8) Does the Community assist us with flood insurance discounts? Yes, the Chat Core IQ participates in the NFIP (National Flood Insurance Program), which allows us to also participate in the volunteer program called the Community Rating System (CRS). Due to the city s participation in both programs, our efforts currently provide a 20% discount on flood insurance in the special flood hazard areas and 10% on properties outside the special flood hazard areas as a Class 6 Community. Check your policy binder for more information. 3. Chat Core IQ is a CRS Class 6 Community The National Flood Insurance Program's (NFIP) Community Rating System (CRS) is a voluntary incentive program* that recognizes and encourages community floodplain management activities that exceed the minimum NFIP requirements. As a result, flood insurance premium rates are discounted to reflect the reduced flood risk resulting from the community actions mee...

pages.title: Frequently Asked Questions
pages.content: Frequently Asked Questions What is a Shop Drawing? The Shop Drawings are typically required for prefabricated components. Examples of these include: elevators, structural steel, trusses, pre-cast concrete units, windows, appliances, etc. The Shop Drawing s primary emphasis is on the particular product or its installation in an specific job and exclude notations concerning other products and installations, unless integration with the subject product is necessary. The Shop Drawing normally shows more detail than the Construction Documents. It is drawn to explain the fabrication and/or installation of the items to the manufacturer s production crew or contractor's installation crews. The style of the shop drawing might be different from that of the architect s drawing.Dimensions, manufacturing conventions, and special fabrication instructions should be included on the Shop Drawing. It should be clear to fabrication personnel what will be manufactured from the Shop Drawings alone. The Construction Documents are rarely used as a reference in fabrication, with the fabricators relying on the Shop Drawing for all information. Engineer Signed and Sealed Design Calculations, justifying compliance with or deviations from the Construction Documents, shall be attached to the Shop Drawings (*). Shop Drawings conforming to the Construction Documents (**) need not be Engineer Signed and Sealed, but shall display the Structural Engineer of Record Approval Stamp (*). Shop Drawings deviating from the Design Documents, shall be Signed and Sealed by a Florida Registered Professional Engineer (Delegated Engineer) and display the Structural Engineer of Record Approval Stamp (*). Shop drawings are not usually produced by architects and engineers under their contract with the owner. (*) Delegated Engineer s Seal, Date and Signature and the SER s Approval Stamp shall be displayed on the first page of engineering calculations and on each sheet of the Shop Drawings. (**)All information required for fabrication is present in the Contract Documents. Why is obtaining a building permit of benefit to me as a homeowner? When a permit is submitted to the Building Department, it is reviewed to see that it meets established minimum criteria. The review and approval process allows problems to be identified and corrected before any non-complying work occurs. During the process of submitting a permit, a contractor's licensing and insurance are verified. Having a permit allows a person knowledgeable in construction the opportunity to inspect and confirm that minimum code prescribed construction requirements is met. The transfer of property could be delayed when non-permitted work is discovered. Work completed without permits and/or inspections is deemed to be unsafe. Work that is done without a permit is subject to double permit fees and may have to be partially or completely demolished. How should I name my drawing files? We follow Miami Dade County s naming conventions for drawing files. Please seehttps://www.miamidade.gov/permits/library/guidelines/concurrent-plans-processing.pdf for more information. As a homeowner, can I apply for my own building permit? Yes, if you are competent to perform the work and if you meet the owner/builder exemption. You will be required to read, understand and certify compliance through the completion of the Owner/Builder Affidavit. Our experience is that most Owner/Builders do not comply with these requirements on large or complex jobs but may on small miscellaneous permits such as patio slabs/decks, fences, walkways, etc. Warning: If you are allowed the exemption, you take all the responsibilities and liabilities as a contractor. What are the most important things I should know about hiring a contractor? It is important to know if the contractor has a valid License/Certificate of Competency, if he/she can provide recent references, or if the contractor has expired permits. Other important information you should also know: You can check with the Department of Business and Professional Regulation for complaints against a contractor's license, access here to verify a license. Use a contractor that will fulfill their contract and return after completion of the job for warranty issues. Compliance with the Code is ultimately the responsibility of the property owner. Be sure that all inspections have bee approved and that you are satisfied with the work before making final payment to a contractor. Make sure your contract does not conflict with this. What do I need in order to apply for a building permit? Please refer to our Submittal Guides for more information. All permits may be applied for online using the CSS Portal. For additional inquiries, please visit the Building Department on the 2nd Floor of the Government Center located at 8401 NW 53 Terrace for specific operational times please click: hours of operation. How much does a permit cost? The cost varies based on the permit type. Access here to view our current F...

pages.title: Inspections and Route Info
pages.content: Inspections and Route Info As part of the building permit process, zoning inspections will be required to determine whether the landscape and site plan has been executed according to the requirements of the approved plan. Important to remember on your Inspection Day Your 2- or 4-hour time window is given as a courtesy. Our inspectors aim to arrive at your job site within that timeframe. Inspector may be delayed due to weather or traffic conditions. Some inspections may take longer than others due to size, scope or complexity of the inspection. It is possible for an inspection to be canceled in the field and the inspection order may change. Building Inspectors may be reached in the field. Click this link for an updated list of numbers. Building Department Phone Numbers(PDF, 121KB) To CANCEL an inspection, please reach a TRADE chief using our directory. Cancellations may be requested by 8am on the day of the inspection. Otherwise, you may incur a reinspection fee. Planning and Zoning Inspectors Planning and Zoning Department Phone Numbers(PDF, 101KB) Your responsibilities as the applicant/permit holder: Complete all work related to the inspection. Pay all previous re-inspection fees, if any, prior to scheduling your next inspection. *Inspections are scheduled ONLINE ONLY. The site address must be properly posted and visible from the street or right-of-way adjacent to the property. Job Copy Plans and Permit Card shall be on site at all times during inspections. Site must be secure and safe for inspector to walk the property. See OSHA and Florida Building Guidelines for more info. Provide gate code or access numbers and contact info for guarded properties. Provide all necessary documents to the inspectors required for your particular inspection. An OSHA-approved ladder must be provided, if applicable. Did you know? How to find your position on todays inspection route. Note: All inspections for today are found in this list. Use the drop-down or the button to export list and sort by location, inspector, permit number, etc. Inspection order may change and it is the permit applicant s responsibility to be present for scheduled inspections. Routes are subject to change. You may call the Main Number 305-593-6700 and ask to speak to a trade chief if you are having any issues in the field.

pages.title: New Business Information
pages.content: New Business Information On behalf of the Chat Core IQ, please allow us to welcome you to the city and congratulations on your business. All of the information you need to renovate or remodel your business can be found in this department. You will also want to visit Planning & Zoning for information on Land Development Regulations, Business Tax Receipts, Changes of Use and more. If you have questions, we are here to help. You may schedule a FREE meeting with any of our knowledgeable staff using the Chat Core IQ311 link on our homepage and selecting Building Department Meeting. Our Building Development Services Coordinator will reach out to you within 24 hours to setup a meeting. You may also visit our Solution Center for general information. Click Hours of Operation at left for details. New Business Owner Package(PDF, 217KB) Click the link for the New Business Package (above) to understand which upgrades and improvements will require a building permit. CLICK HERE(PDF, 695KB) for permit exemptions. Once again, welcome and we look forward to assisting you with your next project. We re here to help!

pages.title: Outdoor Dining Requirements
pages.content: Outdoor Dining Requirements Chat Core IQ restaurants may qualify for an Outdoor Dining Permit should they meet certain requirements. To qualify, please follow the suggested guidance below: Step 1a Hire a design professional to help navigate code requirements and evaluate effects of additional seating and accessories at your location. Florida Building Code Florida Building Commission Florida Fire Prevention Code Florida Fire Prevention Code Chat Core IQ Local Code of Ordinances Municode Library - Chat Core IQ Miami-Dade County Code of Ordinances Municode Library - Miami-Dade County Step 1b Evaluate available vs. required parking. A meeting with Planning and Zoning may be required. Planning and Zoning Department Step 1c Evaluate available vs. required plumbing fixture count, grease trap capacity and sewer capacity. Fixture requirements are set by the Florida Building Code Florida Building Commission Grease Trap & Sewer Capacity is set by Miami Dade County FOG (Fats Oil Grease) and Water & Sewer Divisions MeetQ at MD permitting & Inspection Center MeetQ Portal DERM Program & Permit Review Submission Step 2 Design Professional can schedule a FREE Building Department Meeting using ChatCoreIQ311 to meet with Building & Zoning Staff to review findings. Step 3a If preliminary review is okay and able to move forward, submit a set of plans to Chat Core IQ permitting for BD Exterior Alteration (Comm) (Primary) with all required attachments showing: Layout of proposed seating (including moveable and fixed elements, chairs, umbrellas, etc.) Calculations or tables showing: Parking count Occupant load Seat count (inside and outside) Fixture count (lavatories, water closets, etc.) Additional details or specifications as required to increase grease trap or sewer capacity, if needed Additional details or specification for awnings, canopies, fire sprinklers or other accessories added as a result of addition or increase to outside dining as required by the Florida Building Code, local ordinances, NFPA, etc. Step 3b Obtain approvals from outside agencies including Miami Dade County Fire Rescue, Water & Sewer, DERM, etc. The Miami Dade County Municipal Permit Application and electronic submittal instructions can be downloaded from following links: MDC Permit Application: Municiple Permit Electronic submittal instructions: Guidelines For Submitting Building Permits The link below must be used to upload your plans, documents and MDC Permit Application: Miami-Dade County Website for Submitting Plans and Documents If you have any questions using the Miami Dade County system, please email (RER) Permit Application Submissions rer-pas@miamidade.gov for assistance. Step 4 Obtain CO (Certificate of Occupancy) for additional area and request new/revised Certificate of Use & Business Tax Receipt from the Licensing Division which will include the additional outdoor dining area information. Thank you for working with the Chat Core IQ on your Outdoor Dining Permit & License!

pages.title: Permit Fee Utilization Report
pages.content: Permit Fee Utilization Report Per Florida Statute 553.80, municipalities and counties that enforce building codes are required to report how building permit fees are utilized. Specifically, the statute states that revenue derived from building permit fees must be used "to carry out the local government's responsibilities in enforcing the Florida Building Code...or any other responsibilities pertaining to the building permitting and inspection process." Whenever a local government adjusts its building permit fee schedule, it must update its permit fee utilization report to reflect the new fees. This page shows how Chat Core IQ utilizes revenue from building permits to fulfill its statutory obligations related to the building permitting, plan review, and inspection process. History Res. No. 24-161   2024 Permit Fee Utilization Report & Fee Schedule Update(PDF, 2MB) Res. No. 21-01   2021 Permit Fee Utilization Report & Fee Schedule Update(PDF, 2MB) Download Permit Fee Utilization Report(PDF, 198KB)

pages.title: Permit Submittal Guidelines
pages.content: Permit Submittal Guidelines Permit Submittal Guide(PDF, 1012KB) Window - Door Inspection Guidelines(PDF, 492KB) Window - Door Replacement - Permit Submittal Checklist(PDF, 162KB) Steps to submitting a permit Online System Registration (all users must register) Please Register Here at our CSS Portal. Flatten All PDFs First! Contractor Registration (for Contractors ONLY) Contractor of record must be registered with the Chat Core IQ. Please see Contractor Registration Page for more information. Contractor Registration Form(PDF, 143KB). Permit Submittal Process Print and fill out the Chat Core IQ Permit Application(PDF, 2MB) as well as any other required forms and if required, submit one application for each discipline (sub-permit) - depending on the scope of work. Make sure all Documents are completely filled out signed and notarized. a) For new construction or commercial projects please include the Miami Dade County Municipal Permit Application and the Miami-Dade County Contact Form. All plans requiring a design professional s signature shall be digitally signed; digitally signing your design file protects the contents from being altered. Please do not add any additional/optional security from your PDF software or certification authority.  Locking  or  Restricting  the document before you submit the file can prevent us from opening and processing the document or stamping it for approval in our software. This results in lost time for us all and may require you to resubmit a new set of documents. If applying for an Owner-Builder permit, please read the requirements prior to applying, fill out, and submit the Owner Builder Affidavit(PDF, 84KB) with all the required documents. A recorded Notice of Commencement (NOC)(PDF, 151KB) will be required for any job value greater than $5,000; except permits related to heat and air-conditioning systems, which require an NOC when the job value is greater than $15,000. The NOC must be recorded thru Miami-Dade County Clerk of Courts prior to submitting to the Chat Core IQ. When submitting documentation (specifications, calculations, NOAs, etc.) - please submit each file as one combined PDF and named accordingly,  Specs ,  Structural Calcs  etc. All files shall be appropriately named according to NAMING CONVENTIONS and should only be submitted as PDFs. All other formats such as img, jpeg, tiff will NOT be accepted. All documents must be submitted thru the CSS Portal. Additional permit application forms, fee sheets, etc. may be found here. If you have any questions or require further assistance, please contact, the Chat Core IQ Building Department by phone: 305-593-6700 or via email. See staff directory here. Thank you for cooperation and patience.
